intro: Acaena leptacantha subsp. longiscapa, commonly known as the long-stemmed spinifex, is a perennial shrub native to New Zealand. It belongs to the family Rosaceae and is characterized by its dense, spiny growth habit. The plant produces small, yellowish flowers that are clustered in heads, followed by bright red, berry-like fruits. Its leaves are alternate, simple, and covered in fine, stiff hairs. This subspecies is adapted to dry, sandy soils and is often found in coastal and inland scrub habitats.
distribution_native_art_desc: Acaena leptacantha subsp. longiscapa is primarily native to New Zealand. It is found in the South Island, particularly in the eastern and central regions. This subspecies thrives in a variety of habitats, including forest margins, grasslands, and rocky areas. It is commonly associated with the lower altitude ranges of the Southern Alps. The plant is well adapted to the temperate climate and nutrient-poor soils of its native environment.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Acaena leptacantha subsp. longiscapa was mainly introduced to New Zealand. It was brought there as part of the European flora during the colonial period. This plant has since become naturalized in certain regions of the country. It is commonly found in coastal and lowland areas, particularly in the North Island. However, it is considered a potential weed in some parts of its introduced range.
